workExperience.title: Computer Analyst I
workExperience.employer: Systems Neuroscience Laboratories of Kay Tye
workExperience.organization: The Salk Institute for Biological Studies and Howard Hughes Medical Institute
workExperience.description: Wrote data acquisition pipelines for behavioral training setups and 2-photon microscopes. Maintained multiple NFS databases, as well as the backend of the lab website. Deployed process scheduling platforms on their Debian server system using SunGrid Engine and RunAI. Built multiple decoding and statistical analysis pipelines for neural and behavioral data employing CNNs, DNNs, RNNs, HMMs, PCAs, and many clustering algorithms.

workExperience.title: Barista
workExperience.organization: The RW Kern Center at Hampshire College
workExperience.description: The R.W.Kern Center is the 17th living building in the world boasting a negative carbon footprint and operating as a living laboratory for sustainability research. Here I continued my barista experience and worked to create a pleasant and welcoming environment for campus members during the coronavirus pandemic.

workExperience.title: Field Manager
workExperience.location: Amherst, MA, Provincetown, MA, and Great Barrington, MA
workExperience.description: My job primarily involved cold-canvassing residents throughout the state of Massachusetts. The field managerial position also involved coordinating and scheduling transportation, canvassing routes, safety detail, and supportive leadership for a team of 5 canvassers.

workExperience.title: Administrative Assistant
workExperience.employer: The Institute for Science and Interdisciplinary Studies
workExperience.description: Analyzed the influence of history, politics, economics, and culture to incorporate that analysis into the studies of science and technology. Maintained contact and publication databases.

workExperience.title: Research Assistant I
workExperience.description: Worked on data entry, alignment, quantification, and statistical analysis on cellular microscopy data, genomic data, transcriptomic data, and proteomic data. Through the creation of automated bioinformatic pipelines, publications were able to be completed quicker and more effectively.
